Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of a building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
However, on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he normally get off on the 7th floor? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why the man normally gets off on the 7th floor.
Let me try to break this down step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
That makes sense because he's starting his day.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
Hmm, why not just go straight to the 10th floor? Maybe there's a reason related to the elevator's behavior.
The problem mentions that on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So normally, he doesn't do that.
So there's something about the elevator's operation that changes under these conditions.
Let me think about elevators.
Typically, elevators have buttons that you press to go up or down.
But sometimes, elevators have sensors or are programmed to stop at certain floors automatically.
Maybe the elevator only stops at certain floors under normal conditions, but not others.
Wait, perhaps the elevator only stops at the 7th floor, and then he has to walk up the stairs from there.
So normally, the elevator doesn't go all the way to the 10th floor unless it's raining or someone else is in it.

So why does he get off at the 7th floor normally?

Maybe the elevator has a malfunction or a specific setting.
For example, maybe the elevator is programmed to stop only at the 7th floor, and then he has to walk up.
Alternatively, the elevator might not go beyond the 7th floor unless certain conditions are met, like rain or other people.
But wait, the problem says that when it's raining or there are other people, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So normally, he doesn't do that.
So under normal circumstances, the elevator stops at the 7th floor, and he walks up the stairs.
But when it's rainy or there are others in the elevator, the elevator goes all the way to the 10th floor.
So why does he get off at the 7th floor normally? Maybe because the elevator isn't working properly, or maybe it's set to stop at the 7th floor by default.
Or perhaps the elevator is broken, and he has to get off at the 7th floor and then walk up because the elevator doesn't go further.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator only goes to the 7th floor, and then he has to take the stairs.
So on normal days, the elevator stops at 7, and he walks up.
On rainy days or when the elevator is crowded, it goes all the way to 10.
I think the key here is that the elevator's behavior changes based on certain conditions.
Normally, it stops at the 7th floor, so he gets off there and walks up.
But on rainy days or when there are others in the elevator, it goes directly to the 10th floor.
So, the reason he normally gets off on the 7th floor is because the elevator only stops there, and he has to walk the rest of the way up.
On other days, when the elevator behaves differently, he can go straight to the 10th floor.
I think that's the main point.
The elevator's stopping at the 7th floor is the normal behavior, which is why he gets off there.
The exceptions are when the elevator's behavior changes, allowing him to go all the way up.

The man normally gets off on the 7th floor because the elevator stops there, requiring him to walk up the stairs to his 10th-floor apartment.
On rainy days or when the elevator is occupied by others, it goes directly to the 10th floor, allowing him to bypass the stairs.
